Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: A rarely used machine shows an intermittent glitch during a slow production period.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from my stepdad: “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Let us know how you’re doing!” I know he and Mom expect me to check in, to keep the connection alive, especially since I moved out. I start typing a reply, but before I can finish, my work phone rings. The plant manager’s voice is tense—one of the old packaging machines is acting up, and no one else is around to look at it. I’m the only one on call, even though it’s supposed to be a quiet weekend. I glance at my half-written text, feeling the weight of both worlds. My parents want to hear from me, to know I’m okay, but the machine could halt production if I don’t get there soon. My mind races, torn between the warmth of family and the cold urgency of malfunctioning gears, knowing that whatever I choose, I’ll be letting someone down.
